issue.title: Dilithium5 not enabled
issue.body: Any reason why Dilithium5 is not enabled in the [https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh/blob/OQS-v8/oqs-template/generate.yml#L262](generate.yml) file? On purpose or oversight?

comment.body: As far as I recall it was a random choice when doing #97: I enabled algs such as to get maximum test coverage while not adding too many algorithms (as I also think there's a limit in number of active sig algs): Thus, Dil5AES got enabled instead of Dil5. PR #132 changes this now in line with NIST decisions (also for Sphncs+).

issue.title: Why .cmake files are a part of developer's package
issue.body:
I try to build `liboqs` for Fedora (see https://github.com/beldmit/liboqs-spec as a draft spec) and see several .cmake files as a part of devel package: 
```
-- Installing: /home/dbelyavs/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/liboqs-0.7.2-0.fc36.x86_64/usr/lib64/cmake/liboqs/liboqsConfig.cmake
-- Installing: /home/dbelyavs/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/liboqs-0.7.2-0.fc36.x86_64/usr/lib64/cmake/liboqs/liboqsConfigVersion.cmake
-- Installing: /home/dbelyavs/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/liboqs-0.7.2-0.fc36.x86_64/usr/lib64/cmake/liboqs/liboqsTargets.cmake
-- Installing: /home/dbelyavs/rpmbuild/BUILDROOT/liboqs-0.7.2-0.fc36.x86_64/usr/lib64/cmake/liboqs/liboqsTargets-debug.cmake
```
I'm not a CMake expert. Are they necessary? What is their purpose for the devel package?
Many thanks in advance!

comment.body: Far from being a `cmake` expert myself I added them to permit inclusion of `liboqs` as a `cmake` subproject ([find_package](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/find_package.html) instruction). See #1190. If you know of other approaches, we're all ears.

comment.body:
> CMake fails with a segmentation fault.

Not anymore after `yum update -y`. So here's the full setup:
- Run "docker run -v \`pwd\`:/projects/liboqs -it fedora:rawhide bash" in your local `liboqs` folder
- Within the image run `yum update -y && yum upgrade -y && yum install -y cmake ninja-build openssl-devel gcc && cd /projects/liboqs && mkdir -p build && cd build && cmake -GNinja .. && ninja`

issue.title: Do the bespoke hybrid X.509 certificates conform to the ITU-5 X.509 hybrid (multiple algorithms) certificates?
issue.body:
In 2019, the ITU-T standardised the multiple algorithms certificates (i.e. hybrid) directly in the [X.509 standard](https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-X.509-201910-I/en). It is based on the expired Internet draft by [Truskovsky et al.](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-truskovsky-lamps-pq-hybrid-x509-01).

I was wondering if you plan on implementing this or if this is the implementation that already exists?

comment.body:
> @baentsch I am starting to work on it every day now. The target date will be mid-July.

Thanks for letting us know. Feel free to share thoughts/designs/questions any time: This would ease review/integration (if that'd be a goal for you).

comment.body:
I could build this project on windows with mingw64. However, the tests were skipped in the building process but creating PQC certificates and running a test client and server still works for me.

For the step "Building the provider", likewise as @k-Artin mentioned, I used `while((comma = strchr(alglist, ',')))` instead of `while((comma = index(alglist, ',')))` in `test_common.c`. Moreover, I created a `oqsprov.def` file in the `oqsprov` folder with the following contents:
```
EXPORTS
  OSSL_provider_init
```
Lastly, I added the file `oqsprov.def` to the following section in `CMakeLists.txt` of the `oqsprov` folder.
```
set(PROVIDER_SOURCE_FILES
  oqsprov.c oqsprov_capabilities.c oqsprov_keys.c
  oqs_kmgmt.c oqs_sig.c oqs_kem.c
  oqs_encode_key2any.c oqs_endecoder_common.c oqs_decode_der2key.c oqsprov_bio.c
  oqsprov.def
)
```

Hopefully, cmake will build after the adjustments. It took me a long time to figure out how to build this and I received some help from others. Hope this works for @k-Artin  as well.

comment.body:
Good to hear -- Thanks. 

Would it be an idea/opportunity to add Fedora:latest/rawhide in this way to the .github CI (either the daily or the weekly one) as part of this PR -- kind of "canary test for the latest-and-greatest dev tools"? Or shall we do this separately? Does it make sense at all? @beldmit : Would such "bleeding edge" CI appear sensible -- or overly painful? I guess the question is: How stable is "rawhide"?

comment.body: rawhide is more painful than stable, I think. I'd say use f38 (will be forked on Feb 7, if I'm not mistaken), it's much more stable.
I will check it next week if you don't mind
